Yeah, my post was concerning the current court. And you are right about Miller. The Court recognized that Miller had a right to "bear" arms for individual purposes.   We can go back further than Miller even to find examples of SCOTUS using a non-military/militia interpretation of the 2nd. Amendment phrase "keep and bear arms." In 1875 SCOTUS heard U.S. v. Cruikshank, 92 U.S. 542, which dealt with the federal prosecution of a klansmen for conspiracy to violate a new federal law which made it a crime to deprive a citizen of his fundamental rights guaranteed by the Constitution. Cruikshank was specifically charged with conspiring to deny the black freedmen their fundamental rights of free speech and to keep and bear arms. He did so by leading a band of rioters who burned down a Louisiana courthouse in which armed freedmen had taken refuge while protesting a disputed election.   Like Miller, this was a case involving non-military possession of firearms by private individuals for purposes of private self defense without any connection to a militia function. When klansman Cruikshank sought to deprive the black freedmen of this right, he was prosecuted. This is how SCOTUS described the 2nd. Amendment RKBA:   "The right there specified is that of bearing arms for a lawful purpose." Cruikshank, 92 U.S. at 552. [my bold emphasis]  Again we see a description of the right to keep and bear arms which is not limited to a military context. In this case, the bearing of arms was for the lawful purpose of individual self-defense.   Now this case is often cited by gun control proponents who have seized upon a quote taken out of context in the Court's analysis of the 2nd. Amendment: "The right there specified is that of bearing arms for a lawful purpose. This is not a right granted by the Constitution." Id. [my bold emphasis] Now I have heard gun control proponents cite this quote and argue that this means the constitution does not recognize a RKBA. But that is not what the Court said.   Here is the full quote:  "The right there specified is that of bearing arms for a lawful purpose. This is not a right granted by the Constitution. Neither is it in any manner dependent upon that instrument for its existence. The second amendment declares that it shall not be infringed; but this, as has been seen, means no more than it shall not be infringed by Congress. This is one of the amendments that has no other effect than to restrict the powers of the national government." Id.   What SCOTUS said here is that Bill of Rights did not create rights, it merely recognized certain pre-existing fundamental rights. And this has been a consistent theme in SCOTUS precedent: "The law is perfectly well settled that the first ten Amendments to the Constitution, commonly known as the Bill of Rights, were not intended to lay down any novel principles of government, but simply to embody certain guarantees and immunities which we had inherited from our English ancestors." Robertson v. Baldwin, 165 U.S. 275, 281-82 (1897).   So SCOTUS recognized that the black freedmen had a 2nd. Amendment protected right to "keep and bear arms for a lawful purpose"--like self-defense. SCOTUS also found that these men had a 1st. Amendment protected right to free speech. SCOTUS did not dispute the evidence which showed that Cruikshank, by burning down the courthouse, conspired to deprive these black citizens their free exercise of these rights. Yet SCOUTS reversed Cruikshank's conviction because it held that the Bill of Rights only acted as a limitation on the powers and activities of the federal government, and not those of private citizens or the individual states.   This is an important distinction to remember. SCOTUS has always held that the Bill of Rights acts only to restrict the powers of the federal government. Decades later SCOTUS began using the 14th. Amendment to "incorporate" several rights in the Bill of Rights to make the states recognize and protect them, like the right of free speech, right to remain silent, right to representation by a competent lawyer, freedom from unreasonable search and seizure, etc. All of these were incorporated gradually and individually through a process called "selective incorporation" as cases dealing with these rights came before SCOTUS. But no case has ever come before SCOTUS requiring it to decide whether to incorporate the 2nd. Amendment as a limitation on the power of the states to restrict the RKBA. Unless and until SCOTUS does so, the states are free to thumb their nose at the 2nd. Amendment, and the only restriction on a state's power to infringe on the RKBA comes, if at all, from a recognition of an individual RKBA in its own state constitution.   ---  The issue, however, is not whether court rules are "mutable"; they assuredly are. It is not whether, in the light of "various circumstances," they can be "modifi[ed]"; they assuredly can. The issue is whether, as mutated and modified, they must make sense. The requirement that they do so is the only thing that prevents this Court from being some sort of nine-headed Caesar, giving thumbs-up or thumbs-down to whatever outcome, case by case, suits or offends its collective fancy. Dickerson v. United States, 530 U.S. 428, 455 (2000) (Scalia, dissenting)
That was an interesting quote from Cornell on Cruikshank. I have read Cruikshank. I think Cornell is dead wrong in his analysis of this case, and I think he misunderstands how the Court has implemented the policy of incorporation through the 14th. Amendment. Cornell is right when he suggests that an individual right theory was discussed, because that point was conceded and no one disputed that the black men who suffered under Cruikshank's actions had an individual RKBA. Cruikshank dealt with the question of whether the 2nd. Amendment RKBA could be extended to protection against infringement by an individual citizen's actions. This case did not concern itself with the nature of the civil right (whether individual or collective). Rather, it dealt with the issue of who could be prohibited from acting to violate it. SCOTUS ruled consistently with case precedent that the Bill of Rights acts only to prohibit actions by the federal government.   Now Cruikshank was not, and could not be, a case of incorporation. Cruikshank involved the federal government charging an individual citizen with violating a federal statute which made it a crime to violate the civil liberties of another citizen. The doctrine of incorporation was never an issue in this case because that doctrine is triggered only in cases involving a complaint that the state has acted to deny an individual federal civil liberty which the state should now be to forced to recognize and protect.   Here is an analogy which I hope helps explain my point that incorporation would have been a moot issue in this case. Look at the issue of incorporation as though the federal government were you parents and the state of Louisiana in this case is your big brother. Your parents set out a Bill of Rights for you and they promise to respect those rights. Your big brother then decides to violate one of your rights, and when you complain, your parents smack him for it. When he complains about getting popped, your parents say "hey, that's the doctrine of incorporation-now you're also going to follow my rules son and respect your little brother's rights." Now in Cruikshank, it's your fellow citizen, let's say your racist white brother-in-law, who chooses to violate your rights, and your parents rule on this case by saying "well sorry, the individual right does still exist, but we didn't set these rules up to make him follow them." But if your parents were to have thought out loud, as Cornell seems to suggest, about using the doctrine of incorporation in this case your big brother would whine and say "what did I do?" This would have been the argument of the State of Louisiana if incorporation had been an issue in Cruikshank-"but what did I do?"-because Louisiana did nothing in this case to trigger consideration of the doctrine of incorporation.  I would like to see Cornell's evidence which suggests the doctrine of incorporation was raised and rejected by SCOTUS in a case in which it could not have come into play. If this evidence exists, then it would be historically significant as the only SCOTUS case to do so, and this while at a time of near drought in SCOTUS incorporation decisions. In fact, SCOTUS almost entirely ignored the doctrine of incorporation during that time period.   The only pre-1900 SCOTUS case using the doctrine of incorporation involved arose in 1897, when SCOTUS chose to use the doctrine to incorporate against the states the protection of the 5th. Amendment right to compensation for property taken by the State; Chicago, B. & Q. R. Co. v. Chicago, 166 U.S. 226 (1897). But with the exception of this case, SCOTUS let the doctrine of incorporation languish and did nothing more with it for 30 years until 1927, when it chose to finally require the states to recognize the 1st. amendment rights of speech, press, and religion. Fiske v. Kansas, 274 U.S. 380 (1927), The doctrine was again abandoned for another 20 years, when it resurfaced in a case in which SCOTUS decided to require the states to recognize the 6th. Amendment protected right to a public trial In re Oliver, 333 U.S. 257 (1948). It was then abandoned again until the 1960s, when SCOTUS suddenly became far more active and adopted a deliberate process of "selective incorporation" (4th. Amendment rights to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures and to have excluded from criminal trials any evidence illegally seized; Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 643 (1961); the 6th. Amendment right to counsel, Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335 (1963); the right guaranteed by the 5th. Amendment to be free of compelled self-incrimination; Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U.S. 1 (1964); and to the 6th. Amendment rights to a speedy trial Klopfer v. North Carolina, 386 U.S. 213 (1967), confrontation of opposing witnesses, Pointer v. Texas, 380 U.S. 400 (1965), compulsory process for obtaining witnesses, Washington v. Texas, 388 U.S. 14 (1967), and trial by jury. Duncan v. Louisiana, 391 U.S. 145, 162 (1968)).  The Common thread in every case here is that they all involve a complaint that the state has acted to deny an individual liberty protected in the Bill of Rights. Cruikshank did not, and I am at a loss to understand how Cornell finds a rejection of the incorporation doctrine in this case.   I'm, sorry; I just cannot accept Cornell's analysis of Cruikshank.
I have two thoughts on Cornell's analysis of how SCOTUS dealt with standing in Miller. 1. I think Cornell misses the importance of the issue of standing. 2. I also think his assumption-that SCOTUS could have dismissed Miller's 2nd. Amendment claim for lack of standing but chose not to do so-is wrong because it suggests that SCOTUS acted not only illegally but illogically.  1. Whether we think judges engage in so-called "judicial activism" or not, one key restraint on the power of the federal judiciary has always been the Article III Section 2 requirement that federal courts avoid overstepping their authority by accepting and deciding cases that do not present a "case or controversy." This principle which sets the scope of judicial authority is fundamental that SCOTUS never ignores it. The following cases illustrate how important this point is:  Under Article III, § 2, of the Constitution, the federal courts have jurisdiction over this dispute between appellants and appellees only if it is a "case" or "controversy." This is a "bedrock requirement." Valley Forge Christian College v. Americans United for Separation of Church and State, Inc., 454 U.S. 464, 471 (1982). As we said in Simon v. Eastern Ky. Welfare Rights Organization, 426 U.S. 26, 37 (1976): "No principle is more fundamental to the judiciary's proper role in our system of government than the constitutional limitation of federal-court jurisdiction to actual cases or controversies. One element of the case-or-controversy requirement is that appellees, based on their complaint, must establish that they have standing to sue. Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 561 (1992).Raines v. Byrd, 521 U.S. 811, 818 (1997)  Standing is the "irreducible constitutional minimum" necessary to make a justiciable "case" or "controversy" under Article III, § 2. Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560. Steel Co. v. Citizens for Better Environment, 523 U.S. 83, 84 (1998)  Now without this limitation on the federal judiciary, there is nothing to prevent SCOTUS from interjecting itself into any public policy debate it wants to at any time. This unbridled power has always been rejected by SCOTUS, and to avoid treading into such dangerous ground standing is something that the Court always looks to. In many cases (and I assert Miller is one of them) standing is so clear and unquestioned that no side raises it as an issue and it never gets mentioned. In these cases the law permits us to assume standing exists. In any case where standing is even remotely questionable, however, SCOTUS always deals with that issue on the record in its opinion, and only after it agrees that standing exists will it then rule on the questions presented in the case. The best example I can give you of this process was Roe v. Wade, where the Court struggled with the idea of finding standing for the female plaintiff who at the time the case came before SCOTUS was no longer pregnant. Now SCOTUS clearly wanted to reach and rule on the issue of abortion, but it could not ignore the standing issue to do so. Therefore, SCOTUS dealt with the standing question by declaring that this is a unique case where standing existed because the plaintiff was pregnant when the case was filed, and because of the temporary nature of pregnancy if that standing were to be required when the case reached SCOTUS you could never get a case there fast enough to get it heard:   Pregnancy often comes more than once to the same woman, and in the general population, if man is to survive, it will always be with us. Pregnancy provides a classic justification for a conclusion of nonmootness. It truly could be "capable of repetition, yet evading review." Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113, 125 (1973).   The constitutional point I think Cornell misses is standing is such a fundamental concept that no matter how badly SCOTUS wants to get its hands on an issue, no matter how necessary it feels the need to be to rule on the merits of a case issue, it never ignores or runs roughshod over the question of standing to reach the substance of the case.  2. As I understand Cornell, he argues that SCOTUS could have dismissed Miller's 2nd. Amendment claim for lack of standing but did not do so because "the Supreme Court wanted to make it clear that Congress' regulation of such guns was Constitutional." This first assumes that the Miller Court deliberately chose to violate the Article III Constitutional requirement of standing, and it assumes that SCOTUS did so for an illogical reason.   Miller's claim of a 2nd. Amendment violation was the allegation that his protected individual RKBA was violated by Congress' act banning sawed-off shotguns. If Cornell's assumption is correct-that SCOTUS wanted to approve and protect the power of Congress to regulate these weapons-then the most effectual way to achieve this goal would have been to declare that no individual right exists, and therefore neither Miller nor any other individual citizen has standing to challenge congressional power to ban these weapons. This would be a far greater and more absolute guarantee of that approved congressional power than what SCOTUS actually did-assume that not only could an individual citizen challenge this authority, but if he could also prove that the weapon had some legitimate militia function then he could exempt the weapon from the reach of that authority.   So then if I understand Cornell's argument clearly, he suggests that SCOTUS had a goal of supporting congressional power to regulate certain firearms; that SCOTUS had two options available to do this; and that it deliberately chose the path of violating the Constitution so it could render a decision which actually grants less protection to the congressional power it so wanted to support. I just can't accept the logic of such an argument.
But keeping and bearing arms for what purpose? It seems from the context it is for militia purposes.  The text of second amendment does not limit the right to any specific purpose. There is no qualifier or conditional in the text. Any claim that is for ONLY one purpose is not based on the text -nor would history support such a claim.   However we can say for certain that "bear arms" as used in the Congressional debates on the bill of Rights refers to an individual person's actions and not collective or state action.  At a minimum this phrase refers "to render military service in person" as per  Madison's draft of the amendment and other references describing "bearing  arms" as the action of an individual person.   Madison: "...no person scrupulous of bearing arms, shall be compelled to  render military service in person ". (my emphasis)  George Wyethe of the Virginia convention: "...that any person scrupulous of  bearing arms ought to be exempted upon payment of an equivalent to employ another to bear arms in his stead."  Also the court quoted from the Rhode Island convention: (identical to Wyethe) "...that any person scrupulous of bearing arms ought to be exempted upon payment of an equivalent to employ another to bear arms in his stead."   With this meaning for "bearing arms" in mind, the second amendment then would read:  A well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state, the rigth of the people to keep arms and render militiary service in person shall not be infringed.   While one can certainly argue that the term may be read more broadly, so as to include keeping arms for other purposes such as hunting (as in the VA Militia acti cited in Miller, and the Address of the PA Minority) or self defense (as in John Adams highly influential Defense of the Constitution), one can not plausibly argue that the right to keep and bear arms doesn't include at least how those terms were used during the Congressional debates.
I think the NRA would have to go a lot farther than that if it was truly interested in promoting the Second Amendment. Thomas Scott explained his reason for objecting to the consientious objector clause in the debate about the proposed Second Amendment in the First Congress. He feared that under the proposed clause conscientous objectors would, "neither be called upon for their services, nor [could] an equivalent be demanded."  He said that in such circumstances, "a militia can never be depended upon. This would lead to the violation of another article in the constitution, which secures to the people the right of keeping arms, and in this case recourse must be had to a standing army."  Scott further explained his objection futher, "There are many sects I know, who are religiously scrupulous in this respect; I do not mean to deprive them of any indulgence the law affords; my design is to guard against those who are of no religion. It has been urged that religion is on the decline; if so, the argument is more strong in my favor, for when the time comes that religion should be discarded, the generality of persons shall have recourse to these pretexts to get excused from bearing arms"  He thought non religious people would use the clause to exempt themselves from keeping and bearing arms rather than those who had a legitimate reason.  Scott's fear was people would find a way around the Second Amendment by declaring themselves conscientous objectors. Now people have found another way around the Second Amendment and that is the unorganized militia. People can now claim to belong to the unorganized militia although they may never engage in any type of militia activity. If groups like the NRA were truly interesting in following the Second Amendment they would be advocating the return of such laws as the Militia Act of 1792.   The NRA does support the ownership of militiary style weapons by the general populace, and does encourage marksmanship and proper handling.  Do they support forcing persons like professor Cornell to pay into a fund for delinquents from which poor persons could be provided arms ? I have never heard such a thing proposed by the NRA but I can't say for certain either way.   But considering there are many tens of millions of people willing and able to provide themselves with arms at their own expense, I would say that the militia is much better armed than at any time in the past, and the lack of a fund for delinquents in not a problem that needs addressing.  I am not an NRA member (yet) so I can not say for certain whether they would support state mandated training if it went far beyond basic marksmanship and weapons familiarity. For instance if the states suddenly rekindled an interest in the militia now that the federal government has overworked the National Guard, and set about requiring men between 16 and 60 to report for training for a month at a time, I really couldn't guess what the NRA's response would be.   To my knowledge, the NRA has not proposed any such thing so as in most cases, Cornell's argument does have a small sliver of truth to it. But as usual, he ignores the larger issue -the NRA does support CIVILIAN arms ownership and marksmanship which is the baseline training that is needed for CIVILIAN readiness (i.e. militia). And if Cornell had his way, there would be no civilian readiness whatever.
Cornell's analysis of Cruikshank has really been bothering me. Cornell said that in U.S. v. Cruikshank, 92 U.S. 542 (1875) SCOTUS rejected the incorporation doctrine. I have already addressed how this was impossible since this was not a case of state action.  But now, having re-read Cruikshank, I have lost all respect for Cornell's argument. First, here is the web page where anyone can read the entire Cruikshank opinion.   http://www.usscplus.com/online/index.asp?case=0920542  I post this link because I don't want anyone to have to just take my word for what I am about to say of Cornell's analysis of Cruikshank.   This is the relevant portion of what Cornell said about this case:   "The final nail in that theory was Cruikshank. In that case the individual rights theory was floated by one of the judges who first heard the case, but it was abandoned by the government and rejected by the Supreme Court when the case was finally heard. Rather than adopt a neo-abolitionist point of view and embrace the individual rights view, the Court embraced the views of the Democrats who opposed incorporation and viewed the Second Amendment as a right of the states." http://blog.oup.com/oupblog/2006/07/tushnet_cornell.html (bold emphasis added by me)  Now read the actual case opinion, because I tell you Cornell's analysis is an absolute fabrication of the holding. SCOTUS never said what Cornell wants it to say. SCOTUS never even implied it, and there are only three possible alternatives for how Cornell so poorly misapprehends this case: Either 1. He never read the case and is merely relying on someone else's flawed analysis. OR 2. He read the case but did not understand it, and just decided to assume it says what he wants it to say OR 3. He read the case and chose to deliberately misconstrue what SCOTUS said.   In the records of the Congressional debates about the proposed second amendment it has a military meaning. I think if you look at the big picture you'll find that bear arms was generally a military term and that quoting a few examples where it might have been been used to mean hunting or self defense doesn't change the dominant meaning of the term in the 18th Century. But I think its meaning has evolved over time. State Supreme courts were divided about its meaning in the 19th Century. 19th Century abolitionists insisted slaves had an individual right to bear arms that wasn't connected with militia service.  From a PhD dissertation that examined the early usage of the term: "This paper finds that the overwhelming preponderance of usage of 300 examples of the 'bear arms' expression in public discourse in early America was in an unambiguous, explicitly military context in a figurative (and euphemistic) sense to stand for military service, especially in the militia. Such usage represented a remarkable continuity over nearly two centuries, so much so that the phrase came to represent standard legal terminology describing military obligation, capability, exemption (especially for pacifists), service, and, after 1776, constitutional right." http://www.potowmack.org/emerappa.html#summ   Waving around a vague notion of a "military context" does not answer the question of "who" possessed to right in question.  The one definite answer from a review of the usage of "bear arms" is that the term refers to the actions of individuals.   Which individuals? -would be the next logical question. Since the amendment does not qualify "the people" in any way (no "when in actual service" or any such qualifier) then it must refer to the people as in the other amendments in which the phrase "the right of the people" is used.   For what purpose can the people keep and bear arms? The amendment does not specify that the right to keep and bear arms is to be protected ONLY for service in a militia. There is no conditional attached to "the right ... shall not be infringed".   What you are left to argue is that the words "bearing arms" limits the protections for the possession and use of arms to ONLY those persons on active duty in a state sponsored militia and ONLY for state militia purposes.  But you do not have anything to make your case other than a vague "military constext". I have already mentioned 3 contemporary references to uses of arms by individuals which are not exclusively related to state militia purposes but which are mentioned in a militia act, in a proposal for an amendment guaranteeing the right of the people to bear arms, and in describing the proper role of the militia while defending the authority of the federal government over the militia. Note that each of these references are highly relevant in both time and subject matter to the discussion at hand.   But can you mention even one contemporary reference in which the second amendment or "the right to keep and bear arms" was said to refer ONLY to persons on active duty in the state militia ?    One can hardly imagine a bill of rights to a state constitution containing a right to bear arms provision which referred exclusively to persons enrolled in the armed forces of the state as that would be a pointless guarantee. And yet you claim that is the meaning of the phrase in the context of the second amendment.
 I think the founders wanted the militia to be a well trained and effective fighting force so that they wouldn't have to rely so much on a standing army. Given that militia duty (to constantly keep a supply of arms and render military service in person) was a duty of all free men capable of bearing arms, would not the right be at least as broad?   Instead of contradicting my arguments you are supplying information that supports them.  When people say that the right exists in connection with a militia they are essentially arguing that the right is as broad as the duty but no broader so I'm not sure what your point is above.   My point is that I have cited contemporary references indicating that the right is broader than the duty, and that the right belongs to the individual whether he is on active duty in a militia or not.   What contemporary evidence can you cite in support of your claim that the right to keep and bear arms is no broader than the duty. Under your theory, in cases where a person would be excused from militia duty because of old age or physical disability, would you say that person does not have the right to keep and bear arms ?   Would a person wounded in service to the state and so excused from further active duty, then lose the right to keep and bear arms? Under your theory could the government pass game laws or employ other pretexts for disarming the citizens who were not on active duty in the state military forces?     My purpose in asking these questions is to get more from you than a non-specific statement of a vague "connection with the militia". Note also that the second amendemnt did not bring any rights into existence, rather it guarantees that the right shall not be infringed.   The right guaranteed is not a right of the people to keep and bear arms ONLY in connection with active duty militia sevice, nor is it a right of the people to keep and bear arms ONLY when in actual service. No such qualifiers exist in the text of the amendment, and there is no contemporary evidence to support such an interpretation.

Let me come back to the discussion if I can. Cornell is correct when he urges us to think outside the state's "right" v. individual right views. There is a third rail in the track of this debate which a hybrid "collective" individual right view. It holds that the right is collectively held amongst members of the state-sponsored militias to use their militia arms when called for service by the states. You can reach this argument if you construe "the people" to mean people only in a collective context.  There are a couple of problems with this view. Like the states "right" view, it suffers from the inability to explain why the right is included in several early state constitutions. You could make an argument for a state's or collective individual right in the U.S. Constitution because the amendment was intended to restrict the power of the federal government and thus could be intended to preserve either the power of the state to control the arming of its militia or the right of individuals to collectively carry state-sponsored weapons in service to the state. But if this was the goal, then there is no justification for the right being present in the state constitutions. It cannot be a state's "right," because the state did not need to have the right included in its own constitution to protect it from itself. Likewise, it cannot be a collective right because it would be meaningless-the state again controls the right. If it does not want you to exercise the right, then it merely has to ignore the militia, refuse to enroll anyone in it, and raise a standing army-which would have run counter to the stated fears our founders had of standing armies.  The second problem is this: How do we remain consistent with our interpretation of other rights in the Bill of Rights? Do we interpret the 2nd. Amendment in a vacuum? Do we use one standard for interpreting the other 9 amendments, but reserve an entirely different one for the RKBA? The phrase "the right of the people" is used in the 1st. Amendment. Is "the right of the people" to free speech individual or collective? Can I engage in it on my own like I am doing now, or must I only exercise it in some collective fashion like a mass protest for my speech to be protected? The same phrase "the right of the people" also begins the 4th. Amendment. Is the right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure individual or collective? As an individual driving home from work, do I have a 4th. Amendment protected right not to have my car stopped and searched without probable cause, or is the right collective and therefore applying only to public mass transportation like a bus or the D.C. metro? Do I have an individual 4th. Amendment right to be free from having my home searched without probable cause and a warrant, or is the right collective and only protecting mass meeting houses like churches or sporting arenas?   The answer to all of these questions is the phrase "the right of the people" means an individual right every time it is used. We can't take the exact same phrase and say "people" means an individual person in the 1st. Amendment, then a collective mass of persons in the 2nd. Amendment, only to morph the word back to meaning an individual person in the 4th. Amendment.

Historian Gary Wills explains that keep does not necessarily mean keep at home. It could mean the people keep their guns in some type of communal armory "Gun advocates read 'to keep and bear' disjunctively, and think the verbs refer to entirely separate activities. 'Keep,' for them, means 'possess personally at home'- a lot to load into one word. To support this entirely fanciful construction, they have to neglect the vast literature on militias.....Some arms could be kept at home, course. Some officers kept their most valuable piece of war equipment, a good cross-country horse, at home, where its upkeep was a daily matter feeding and physical regimen. But military guns were not ideally kept home." http://www.potowmack.org/garwills.html  If it does mean keep at home what would that mean in our day? Gary Wills shows how silly he can be when suggesting that if the founders wanted the people to have the right to Keep arms at home they would have specified that right. Paraphrasing the eminent linquist: If Coingress wanted us to have the freedom of speech at home, they would have been more specific.   Of course, as any 4th grader knows, the words "at home" would act a qualifier placing a limit on the right. As it stands, the freedom of speech is unqualified and so there is absolutely no need to specifiy that we have the right to freedom of speech at home.   On the other hand, if Congress had wanted individuals to keep their arms only in central stores, they would have specified that in the Second Amendment and in the 1792 Militia Act -but they did not!   And yes, "unqualified" in Aymette refers to there being no further (the right included all free white men) qualifications on WHO may bear arms under the Tenn. constitution which was far broader in that regard than the British bill of rights. There is no mention of having to be on active duty or even enrolled in the militia in order to keep arms, and that is the case even in the Tenn. constitution in which the phrase "for the common defense" follows the right to bear arms.   The Second amendment is broader still since it refers to "the people" and does not contain the qualifier "for the common defense".     That may have been the true intent but that does not necessarily mean its use of language was standard. . John Adams may have favored arms for personal self defense but did he say that this is what is meant by the right to bear arms? .   What he said is much, much worse for your argument. He said that in reference to the mililita, and to the purposes that it would be acceptable for individuals to have arms in their hands. Your incessant attempts to limit the use of arms only to militia purposes is completely undercut, as Adams is on record in a highly influential paper saying that private self defense is a legitamate use of arms. I suppose Adams is also a lone dissenter, eh?  In case you still don't get it, private self defense was used by a highly influential Founder and Framer in a highly influential treatise as a legitimate use of arms in a discussion of the proper role of the militia. Thus making it difficult for one to argue that the only uses of arms protected by the second amendment are those with a connection to the militia, and at the same time try to exclude private self defense.      "Supporters of the individual rights view have focused on the fact that Coxe asserted that 'the people are confirmed by the next article in their right to keep and bear their private arms.' While at first glance this would seem to provide proof of an individual right, it is not clear in what capacity the people's private arms are protected. Are they protected as private citizens or are they protected because as militiamen citizens were expected to provide their own weapons for militia duty? Coxe's statement ultimately tells us little about how people understood the individual or collective nature of the right to keep and bear arms in the late-eighteenth century." http://historymatters.gmu.edu/d/5200  So the Coxe quote doesn't necessarily tell us for what purpose it was protected. . Furthermore he says "private arms" which means that in his view the right is private, belonging to the person -do you recall the Blackstone quote you cited a few posts ago?     In Madison's first draft of the Second Amendment bear arms clearly has a military meaning. In the debates in the first Congress it also had a military meaning.   From a PhD dissertation that examined the early usage of the term: "This paper finds that the overwhelming preponderance of usage of 300 examples of the 'bear arms' expression in public discourse in early America was in an unambiguous, explicitly military context in a figurative (and euphemistic) sense to stand for military service, especially in the militia." http://www.potowmack.org/emerappa.html#summ So I don't think the claim can be easily dismissed. Just because one come up with a few quotes where it might have had a non military meaning doesn't change the big picture. .  Except those "few quotes" aren't so few, and they relate very closely both in time and topic to the right to keep and bear arms. Also some of those usages were widely published at the time so would undoubtedly have informed a good portion of the public about the meaning of the second amendment. I like reading Amar, but I'm going to have to disagree with his "communitarian analysis" of the BoR. He wants to read the phrase "the people" in the 2nd. as exclusively collective in context. To reach this conclusion, he unequivocally asserts "[t]he rest of the Bill of Rights confirms this communitarian reading." The admitted stumbling block in his analysis is the 4th. Amendment: "The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated...."   I believe he would have been better off ignoring the 4th. Than engaging in the speculative guesswork he did. He begins with:   "Here, the collective "people" wording is paired with more individualistic language of "persons." And these words obviously focus on the private domain, protecting individuals in their private homes more than in the public square."  Now Amar cannot argue that the phrase "the people" means a collective right in the 4th. He knows that this phrase was viewed by our founders and by all courts which have ever considered this amendment to be a right of each individual citizen. His mention of the 4th.'s inclusion of the word "persons" is meaningless. Indeed, I cannot understand why he felt it important enough to mention it only to studiously avoid any analysis of it. Here is mine: "The people" in the amendment refers to individual citizens who have a right to be secure in their (individually possessive) "persons." Here, the use of the word "persons" merely confirms that the phrase "the people" also refers to individuals.   But Amar still will not let the collective definition go: "Why, then, did the Fourth use the words "the people" at all?" Here is where I believe Amar overreaches the most:   "Probably to highlight the role that jurors--acting collectively and representing the electorate--would play in deciding which searches were reasonable and how much to punish government officials who searched or seized improperly."   Again, there is no analysis of this argument. He cites no example, no statement, no court precedent or procedure to support this guesswork. This is because none exists. I have been immersed in the 4th. Amendment for over 15 years now. I deal with it on a near daily basis. In our criminal justice system, juries never have, and never did, play any role in deciding which searches or seizures violated the 4th. Amendment. These are always questions of law decided in hearings and arguments before judges. On the civil side of the law, individuals (because the phrase "the people" refers to individuals) can sue the government and have government officials punished financially for violations of their 4th. Amendment right. I doubt, however, that this is what Madison was referring to. The ability to file such a lawsuit did not exist until Congress passed legislation permitting it in 1979 (42 U.S.C. 1983). If we argue that Madison would have used the phrase "the people" to refer to jury vindication of a violation of a civil right, when juries were neither intended nor permitted to do so by any of his amendments, and in fact could not do so until authorized by congressional statute 200 years later, then we suggest that Madison should have a far greater reputation for prescience than Nostradamus.   Amar completely fails to link such an oblique speculation. His only argument in favor of his guess (for that is all it is) is to point to an earlier, rejected draft of the 6th. Amendment right to trial by jury-chosen, presumably, because it contains the phrase "as one of the best securities to the rights of the people, ought to remain inviolate." No where in this cited example does Madison state or even remotely suggest that juries should act collectively to protect the right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure (nor does this imputation exist in the adopted 4th. Amendment).   Use of this example does, ironically, support the individual right view. It is yet another example of Madison's penchant for including universally believed statements in the amendments he was drafting. These statements of principle, like the 2nd. Amendment militia preamble, have no impact on the right itself. They merely state one (of many) public rationales for the importance of protecting the right. The phrase quoted by Amar does not limit the 4th. Amendment right at all, it merely states that the right was viewed important enough to be included in his Bill of Rights (because it is one of the "best securities" of the rights of the people). The same is true of the militia preamble, which informs us that standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and that to secure a "free" state we should rely instead upon a militia. As I have argued before, there are many examples of Madison and other draftsmen of his time including these goals or principles with the substantive right. It is only with the RKBA that anyone seems encouraged to argue a statement of principle should be used as a rope to strangle the right it accompanies.

Might a person enroll and never be called to service?   If the government never calls an individual to service, does that individual lose his right to keep and bear arms? When does this happen? After 1 year w/o service?, 10 years?, or 20 years? Is there any historical evidence that this is the case?   Does each of us have a right to enroll ? Does government have a duty to enroll all of us? If so, what is to be done if the government refuses? If a person wants to enroll but is denied without cause by government , does that person still have a right to keep and bear arms?   Doesn't the government naturally control who may (and who must) enroll in the organized militia? Does the right to keep and bears arms apply to militia that are not trained periodically?   We have a right to keep and bear arms -which means at the very least that we have a right to keep arms and to render military service in person -but does that mean we have a right to enroll in the organized militia, or to decide when we will go on active duty and/or when we will be merely reserves?  Does the second amendment require that the goverment train everyone? Or is the government free to organize and train only a portion of the militia?

As to the federalist papers, they were written between 1787 and 1788. The first ten amendments to the constitution were not ratified until 1791. Three years later. Those papers do not refer to the bill of rights. In fact, there were only three authors, John Jay, James Madison, and alexander hamilton.  In fact, lets look at one of the things that Hamilton says:  If standing armies are dangerous to liberty, an efficacious power over the militia, in the body to whose care the protection of the State is committed, ought, as far as possible, to take away the inducement and the pretext to such unfriendly institutions. If the federal government can command the aid of the militia in those emergencies which call for the military arm in support of the civil magistrate, it can the better dispense with the employment of a different kind of force. If it cannot avail itself of the former, it will be obliged to recur to the latter. To render an army unnecessary, will be a more certain method of preventing its existence than a thousand prohibitions upon paper.    Clearly Hamilton envisioned the militia was the people of the country. He advised that the states be the ones to regulate such militias. However, he clearly intends that people be called up with their own weapons in case of insurrection and invasion.  The right to keep and bear arms is essential as the point of "calling up the militia was only in times of domestic disturbance (to include invasion) where every man will be in the path of destruction. The standing army for internal protection was never contemplated. An army would be contemplated for foreign wars.  Huck

This discussion came up on another forum, with what appear to be some of the same participants. Here is a copy of the post I made on the subject.  Before ripping the original post to shreds, I must say that the gun control folks make it way to easy to counter their emotional remarks... While the .50BMG is capable of impressive accuracy at long range, it is not simply a matter of putting the cross hairs on a target and pulling the trigger. To understand this, we have to look at the nature of projectiles in free flight, more commonly know as the study of ballistics. A bullet in flight is constantly slowing down and being drawn by gravity towards the earth. The farther it travels, the slower it goes, the more profound the effect of gravity is. Thus the arc of a bullet in flight is a parabolic arc rather than a linear arc. This is why you have to either adjust sights or aim higher as you increase the distance to the target. Let's look at the trajectory of a typical military loading. The following data aplies to the M-2 military ball weighing 709 grains with a muzzle velocity of 2,850fps. Distances are listed in yards and bullet drop is listed in inches.  Distance to target / Bullet drop  100/ 0- this is the distance at which we have zeroed our sights meaning that point of aim=point of impact 200/ -4.8 300/ -14.6 400/ -30.2 500/ -52.2 600/ -81.2 700/ -118 800/ -162 900/ -218 1000/ -284  Now for wind...Just like distance to the target, any effects from wind drift will result in a parabolic arc as well, because the wind has a longer period of time to act on the bullet within a given distance as the bullet slows down. A 10mph crosswind requires 56 inches of correction for a target that is at 1000 yards. This is if the 10mph wind remains constant throughout the distance to the target, which is seldom the case. Everything from wind shifts to geographic features will cause the effect of wind to vary from the time the bullet is launched, to the time that it arrives at the target.  Moving targets...unfortunately bullets do not arrive at the target the instant we pull the trigger. The time of flight allows for a target to move out of the path of bullet. Let's assume a human target at walking speed of 2mph. A target at 1000 yards moving at 2mph would require you to lead the target by about 48 inches, or four feet. If we increase the speed of the target to 6mph our lead jumps to 144 inches! That's twelve feet!! And this is just for a target moving 6mph.  Using this new found knowledge, let's look at the possibility of hitting a moving commercial aircraft. A 737 on approach for landing travels at about 150mph. This is slower than climb out speed so I chose this scenario to give the best possible chances of actually hitting it. At this speed we would have to lead the target by more than 300 feet. We would also have to constantly calculate and update the distance to the plane during the time leading up to the shot and adjust our aiming point to accommodate the distance. Oh, and don't forget that the plane is also moving in the vertical plane at a rate of 700 to 1000 feet per minute to stay on the glide slope for landing, so we have to account for that too. And don't forget the effect of wind, once again acting to shape our trajectory in a parabolic arc that increases or decreases in radius relative to distance. Wow!!! THAT"S A LOT OF ON THE FLY CALCULATIONS!!!! What super computer did you say we were using to aim this thing?? Oh yea, this is also assuming that you could get within 1000 yards of the aircraft carrying a gun that is 5 feet long and weighs between 20 and forty pounds. Any doubt as to how ridiculous this claim is???  One round could tear an arm of a man even if the round was 3 feet away from him.   For this to be a possibility, it would have to be caused by the disruption of air around the bullet as a result of it's velocity. The simplest answer to this one is...If this were true, why does the same bullet at the same velocity punch nice clean holes in paper targets without tearing it to shreds?  It could put holes in destroyers hulls and shred people in a manner of seconds.   Even with armor piecing ammunition, the .50BMG penetrates only 1 inch of homogeneous armor plating from a distance of 200 yards. Having spent fiver years in the Navy, I can assure you that the armor plating on a destroyer is MUCH thicker than this.   well its still dangerous enough to kill people especially children   As was stated by others, any gun can be used to kill. The argument of "no legitimate sporting purpose" holds no water either. The .50 BMG is frequently used for both hunting and target applications. On top of that, our second amendment makes no stipulation that the right to keep and bear arms is dependent on "Sporting purpose". On the contrary, the second amendment was intended to insure that the people of this nation had the means to resist a tyranical government. Based on that premise, the .50BMG is perfectly legitimate. Omegamon,   I have been to Knob Creek, but not in several years. I typically do not have the time with all that I have on my plate.   Ethmi,   While it may seem odd, the typical naval vessel is not terribly well armored. The heaviest armor runs from the deepest draft point on the hull (this varies by ship mass due to loading, so the armor is extended above the point at which the ship would sit lowest in the water) down to the keel. This is to protect against torpedo attack. the upper levels of the hull are actually much thinner to conserve weight. The hull is a double wall arrangement stiffened with strut structures called frames, and are even partitioned for storage of fuel oil, potable water, chill water and waste, as well as other commodities. The 'superstructure", those decks above the main weather deck or flight deck in the case of a carrier, are constructed from mild steel typically 3/16" thick. Armor is less necessary on the upper decks, because the threat is more likely to be a missile than bullets. I am pretty sure that all modern Naval vessels, with the exception of submarines, employ the CWIS defense system. This is a six barreled 20mm Gatling cannon that is aimed and fired through a radar fire control system. When a threat (missile, plane, ect.) is identified as a threat, the fire control system tracks the target, measuring mass, range, speed and rate of closure. When a firing solution is derived, the system fires 11mm depleted uranium sabot rounds driven by aluminum "pushers" at a rate of 4000 rounds per minute. The fire control system continues to fire until the mass of the target is reduced by a specific percentage, sorry, but I don't recall all of the particulars. Typically there are at least two CWIS mounts on board ship and the tracking system has the ability to track many inbound threats and engage them with blazing speed and deadly accuracy. Did I mention that my Primary rating in the Navy was as a Gunner's Mate? LOL  JW

Review of the "Big Bear" tables suggest that the information is either incorrect or not drawn from the same source. The first table represents total murders per capita. The second represents firearm related murders per capital. One would presume then that since firearm murders are a portion of total murders, the former must be smaller than the latter.  That is not so here. Total murders per 1,000 people in South America is listed as .496 per 1,000 whereas the number of murders per firearm is listed as .720 per 1,000. This indicates to me that one or both of the studies is flawed, or that they are not derived from the same data. In either case, We cannot rely upon the information provided.

Very interesting. I wonder how the people who claim that gun laws have no effect on criminal behaviour explain the much lower rates of criminal gun use in other nations. It seems that pro-gun theory would predict that this would not be so since gun advocates claim that guns laws will never affect criminal behaviour. If gun laws actually affect criminal behaviour then there should be a statistical correlation between legal gun ownership and increase in gun crimes. And to put it bluntly, there isn't. How else do you explain the fact that many countries where guns are illegal rank higher on the gun death list than countries where guns are legal? Canada, Switzerland, Finland and scores of other countries allow for legal gun ownership but don't have a higher number of gun deaths than countries where guns are illegal.

SUMMARY: The international comparisons are completely bogus because they selectively address only a few countries, because they ignore the many significant differences between the countries, and because they ignore the fact that some of the countries had still lower death rates in the past when they had more firearms. They know there is a decent chance they won't get caught and even if they do get caught there is a good chance they can beat the system and get off scott free. The risk is well worth the reward for them. Watch the discovery channel show "It takes a Thief" at some point. Check out what kinda loot the guy gets from the places he robs.   On the other hand Imediate concequences have a more intresting effect and are a great deturent from criminal action. If a person knows they stand a 50-50 chance of getting killed by breaking into a house chances are very very good that they will decide the risk is not worth the reward by a longshot. A sholdered lightweight carbine rifle I think would serve pretty well all around.  A rifle is a poor weapon for entry or building sweeps. The problem with sweeping a building is the doorways and hallways. You have a poor field of view there and no real escape route. Bad guys know this, which is why the most common ambush point during building sweeps is at a doorway.  Do a little experiment. Get a rifle. Make certain the weapon is empty and safe. Have somebody grab the barrel and try to take control of the rifle. You cannot possibly maintain control of that weapon. Try the same with a pistol, holding it in a proper 2 hand grip, and it is virutally impossible for them to take it away from you because in that situation YOU have the leverage AND a better grip. I was explainging this to my wife at one point and despite the fact nobody is ever going to call me "pewee" and the fact that my wife is small, i can not hold onto the barrel of that pistol if she pulls straight back.   This is why you see insanely short tactical stocks on the MP5. They are trying to shortent he weapona nd bring it in to the point that a bad guy has less of a chance to grab it, and the guy weilding the weapon has SOME chance of maintaining control. Even when you are talking Navy Seals or Delta, they are taught NOT to try to retain full control of the weapon, but rather to fight for it with one hand and draw their pistol and kill the perp with the other...and these are professionals.   Ultimatly homeowners should probably not be sweeping their homes anyway...they should choose a barricade position where they can put up a defense. Behind a bed with their rifle/shotgun pointed at the door is a good choice...as is laying at the top of the stairs with your weapon ready. They fact that SHOULD NOT be sweeping the house does not mean that they WILL NOT. When considerign defensive weapons, that has to be considered. You have to plan for worst case, so you assume that your homeowner will be half asleep, stumbling through the house with a weapon they are not particularly skilled with, in search of an adversary who has planned ahead and knows what they are doing. In that situation, a pistol is the only real choice for a weapon. Short range instinctive shots with a pistol have a VERY high hit rate. With a rifle that rate is much lower. when you are talking home invasion youa re talkin a range measured in feet, not yards. The addition power and accruacy inhernt to a rifle, or even a carbine, are not required.

I have never managed to accidentally discharge a revolver either, and I have several of them. I have had a .45 accidentally discharge when I released the slide on a new magazine (gun was broken). I once had an ruger 10/22 discharge when I dropped it in the bed of a truck. Beyond that I have never had an accidental discharge and I do a LOT of shooting with a lot of different weapons.   The VAST, VAST majority of accidental discharges can be traced to 2 root causes:  1. An intentionl pull of the trigger by somebody who thought the gun was empty  2. Some XXXXX wandering around with their finger on the trigger.   I can not recall ever hearing of a revolver discharging when it was not due to one of those two things. Typically revolvers can be dropped, thrown, hit, bumped, and generally mistreated and they still do not go off without pulling the trigger. BTW, that "+1" in the chamber may get you in trouble some day.  Aside from faulty trigger mechanisms, there's no discharge that occurs without some deliberate action on the part of the user. The single actions must be cocked first...then the trigger activated. The double actions are virtually impossible to fire accidently unless you c o c k them first rather than use the trigger pull for cocking. Most of the good revolvers have mechanisms that keep the firing pin away from the casing unless the trigger is back, making it virtually impossible to fire by dropping the gun or striking the hammer forward from the outside.  I've had several revolvers...S&W K22 Magnum (sweet shooter), S&W stainless steel .38 Chief's Special, S&W .38 Hammerless, S&W .38 LiteWeight (amazing), Colt .357 Python (amazing, especially when shooting .38 Specials) and some others. Kansas has, IMO, some of th emost effective gun control laws in the nation. They have nothing to do with banning guns, they instead seek to punish criminal use of firearms. For example, if you are caught wiht a firearm while in the comission of a burglary, you get an automatic 5 years. That is a GOOD gun control law. Since it was passed, the incidents of burglars with firearms has decreased by nearly 80% in Ks. They are not willing to risk the extra 5 years. There is a whole myriad of crimes that net stiff additional, mandatory penalties if you carry a firearm.  Most gun control legislation has no crime control component at all. The only logical conclusion that I think can be crawn from such bills is that those who support them care nothing about crime, they are simply interested in disarming law abiding citizens.

When I was a kid, it was offered in elementary school as an after school class that they had for 5 days.   I see no reason why we could not require a safety class for those wanting to purchase or carry a pistol. Make it a 1 day class or something that can be half classroom and half practical application. Once you are done, you get a "safety card" that precludes you from having to take any classes again. This is one of the very few gun control measures that I support that is not aimed at crime prevention.

I would not be opposed to requiring safety classes as long as the following conditions are met:  1. They are free 2. Requirements for passing the class are NOT set by the government.   I think the first one is important because you are talking about a right, not a privelage, and poor people should be able to exercise their rights as well. While $50 once for a class is probably not a lot for many people here, to a poor person it may be and I am not willing to risk stripping an entire class of their RKBA based on their financial situation.  The second is important because in the past many states have had restrictions for concealed carry that were related to the education requirement. Most states now (all "shall issue" states) that have an educational requirement for concealed weapons carry specify an "NRA approved" firearms course. To me, that is acceptable. It meets the educational goal of the states while ensuring that the educational requirements are not prohibitive.

I disagree with Kellerman's 4/1 ratio claim that you ask me to keep in mind. He has a history of first assuming a result and then creating studies using deliberately small and target skewed sampling to prove the point he wants to make. This 1998 study in particular demonstrated blatantly biased methodology. He had at his disposal several years of nationwide data, both urban and rural to choose from, and he samples only 626 events from only three cities. Now I can easily name ten incidents I know of where a homeowner brandished a firearm to run off an intruder. I can then tell you of only one of the incidents I know of where a firearm was used to take a relative's life in a home, and from my statistics I can conclude that a gun is 10 times more likely to be used in self defense than to commit a domestic homicide. My "study" would be as biased and worthless as Kellerman's.   This 1998 study is not the only time Kellerman has engaged in questionable statistical sampling. His most famous study-- the one in which he used approximately 300 shootings to conclude that a gun in the home was 41 times more likely to kill a family member than an intruder--was removed from Brady Campaign publications after it was exposed as a fraudulent study. Kellerman's research is akin to arriving at a crowded cocktail party and looking over the heads of all the guests for the few friends he recognizes huddled together in the corner. His studies do not reflect what I have experienced. The vast majority of defensive gun use does not involve a homicide.   Yes, I believe I can fight fire with fire. I agree with your statement that guns will always be circulated easily. With that in mind, I would prefer to be armed and prepared to fight fire with fire than be unarmed and forced to fight fire with say, a handful of straw. I've been threatened with death more than once before, and I have resolved to be armed and prepared should anyone ever attempt to act on their threats.  No knowledgeable self-defense expert will recommend using a knife to hunt down an intruder over taking a stand in an easily defended area of your house with a firearm.   I disagree with a frozen in time approach to civil liberties. If this view prevailed, then my bloging would be limited to a printing press, and my political speech would be limited to the reach of my voice from the top of an overturned soapbox. Thanks for responding, Unriggable. Let me address the points you raise....  I'm going to disagree with the idea that mandatory locks would deter gun thefts. Locks are designed primarily as a safety measure to prevent an unauthorized person (such as a child) from firing a gun. They are not designed to deter a thief, who once he has stolen the gun can take as long as he wants to cut the lock. Therefore, I a disagree that mandatory locks would create a theft deterrent.   I also see no valid reason to force otherwise law abiding individuals to wait when purchasing a firearm. The claim that a waiting period deters crimes of sudden passion has always been a sham argument. The instant check system has been used for over a decade now, and there have been no reported increases in crimes committed with a gun purchased on the spur of the moment. Therefore, I see no justification for restricting access to a fundamental right when it serves no legitimate purpose.  Now a permit/registration scheme is an interesting issue which comes with a few problems. The first problem would be the potential for massive passive resistance to a registration or permit scheme, like what we have seen in Canada. In my opinion it would be impossible to construct a permit or registration scheme that would cover the vast secondary (individual to individual "street" sales) market. The only way to enforce a permit or registration scheme would be to criminalize it and prosecute persons who get caught with a gun they did not register or did not obtain a permit for. This may be fine and good in the abstract, but in reality it would have no impact on fighting gun crime other than to make inadvertent criminals out of otherwise law-abiding gun owners.  I say this because there will be a number of people who would be exempt from a permit or registration requirement. Convicted murderers, rapists, robbers, home burglars, child sexual offenders, or indeed any other convicted felon would be exempt. Also exempt would be convicted stalkers, persons found guilty of domestic violence, and persons previously involuntarily committed to a mental health institution for either past violence or the potential for future violence. We talk all the time about keeping guns out of these "wrong" hands, and these are the very people who would be immune from prosecution for refusing to submit to a mandatory permit or registration scheme. Here's why:   It is a crime for these persons to possess a firearm. If the state mandates that they announce their possession of a firearm through obtaining permits or registering firearms then it forces them to incriminate themselves in violation of their 5th. Amendment right.   This has been tried before. In 1968 Congress enacted a number of firearm restrictions under the title of the National Firearms Act. The NFA contained a mandatory firearm possession registration scheme; which required all persons to register possession of and be taxed on their possession of certain classes of firearms Congress determined were being used principally by persons engaged in unlawful activities. The registration scheme was enforced by two new criminal statutes: 26 U.S.C. § 5841 made it a crime for failure to register possession of a particular type of firearm, and 26 U.S.C. § 5851 made it a crime to possess an unregistered firearm. SCOTUS declared that prosecutions for a violation of these registration requirements was unconstitutional because registration compelled self-incrimination--See Haynes v. United States, 390 U.S. 85 (1968). Now we could try to avoid the constitutional challenge by calling it a "permit" scheme instead, but SCOTUS looks at the application of a law and not the title Congress gives it when deciding constitutionality, and a mandatory "permit" scheme is equivalent to a registration scheme in both its requirement of self-incrimination and its purpose of establishing a nationwide database.  Therefore, I would oppose a permit/registration scheme because it would punish the innocent while ignoring the guilty.   ---  "False is the idea of utility that sacrifices a thousand real advantages for one imaginary or trifling inconvenience; that would take fire from men because it burns, and water because one may drown in it; that has no remedy for evils, except destruction. The laws that forbid the carrying of arms are laws of such a nature. They disarm only those who are neither inclined nor determined to commit crimes. Can it be supposed that those who have the courage to violate the most sacred laws of humanity, the most important of the code, will respect the less important and arbitrary ones, which can be violated with ease and impunity, and which, if strictly obeyed, would put and end to personal liberty--so dear to men, so dear to the enlightened legislator--and subject innocent persons to all the vexations that the guilty alone ought to suffer? Such laws make things worse for the assaulted and better for the assailants; they serve rather to encourage than to prevent homicides, for an unarmed man may be attacked with greater confidence than an armed man. The ought to be designated as laws not preventative but fearful of crimes, produced by the tumultuous impression of a few isolated facts, and not by thoughtful consideration of the inconveniences and advantages of a universal decree." Thomas Jefferson, Commonplace Book, 1774-1776, quoting 18th century criminologist Cesare Beccaria in On Crimes and Punishment, 1764.

There are two points to address with the mandatory gun locks deterrent argument. The first is whether a mandatory law would deter home burglaries to begin with, and the second is whether they would help prevent or deter gun theft in the event of a burglary.  In my opinion a mandatory trigger lock law would not deter burglaries from occurring. Guns are stolen because they are portable, concealable, and have a high street value. So are TV's, DVD players, jewelry, keys to the spare car, prescription drugs, computers, etc. Burglars know we are not locking these things up, and they know they are far more likely to find these items of value in a break-in anyway. Mandatory locks designed to prevent burglars from stealing only one of 20 or more types of coveted items does not in my opinion deter the burglary from occurring.   Would a mandatory trigger lock law then help prevent gun thefts from a burglary? I don't think they would. Locks do not affect the portability of firearms-and a thief can take the gun quickly from the larceny scene to another, safer location where he can work on breaking it at leisure.   On the question of gun safes, they can be broken into as well, but they are far better at preventing gun loss if a burglary occurs than trigger locks. Burglars are not typically armed with the tools necessary to defeat a gun safe. If the thief does show up with the tools to "crack" a gun safe, then he must be prepared to spend a great deal of time exposing himself to capture at the crime scene while "cracking" it. The alternative is for the thief to draw attention to himself by showing up with the necessary equipment to move and transport such a heavy and difficult to conceal object. When gun safes are defeated it typically comes in break-ins where the burglar knows the home owner will be away for several days and he can take his time drilling out the lock.   On the question of police response times, I believe a three minute average is too optimistic. I have seen calls responded to that quickly, but they are a lucky few. Everything has to fall in place perfectly-an unoccupied officer has to happen to be nearby when the call comes in. If we rely on the police alone then we have to pray that when we call 911 those officers are not already several miles away at another call fighting to arrest a drunk who beat his wife. It is a very rare event for officers to arrive quickly enough at a home burglary to catch the thief "in the act."  --- And indeed, gentlemen, there exists a law, not written down anywhere but written in our hearts; a law which comes to us not by training or custom or reading but by derivation and absorption and adoption from nature itself; a law which has come to us not by theory but from practice, not by instruction but by natural intuition. I refer to the law which lays it down that, if our lives are endangered by plots or violence or armed robbers or enemies, any and every method of protecting ourselves is morally right. When weapons reduce them to silence, the laws no longer expect one to await their pronouncements. For people who decide to wait for these will have to wait for justice, too--and meanwhile they must suffer injustice first. Indeed, even the wisdom of the law itself, by a sort of tacit implication, permits self- defense, because it does not actually forbid men to kill; what it does, instead, is to forbid the bearing of a weapon with the intention to kill. When, therefore, an inquiry passes beyond the mere question of the weapon and starts to consider the motive, a man who has used arms in self-defense is not regarded as having carried them with homicidal aim. Cicero , Selected Political Speeches, p. 222 (M. Grant, trans. 1975) Defense of habitation and justifiable self-defense overlap in the "castle doctrine" which states that one may, without retreating, use force, to include deadly force if necessary, to keep aggressors out of his own house. This part of the castle doctrine is one aspect of defense of habitation. . . . [T]he justification exists in the curtilage as well as the castle. Roger D. Groot, Criminal Offenses and Defenses in Virginia 114 (3rd ed. 1994)

I get into constant arguments with people about this. This is the most common one I get.  "But I don't feel safe with any one having a gun. Only police officers and security guards should carry and have them."   First of all, feeling safe is NOT a right...that's a state of mind. It seems people think feeling safe is somehow a right, it's NOT. Self-defense IS a right. That is right granted by the Constitution, specifically the 2nd Amendment. In no where does it say "only police officers or military, etc" it says the people! Secondly, citizens with CCW (concealed weapons permits) are just a capable as police officers and security guards. Most if not all CCW holders have to go through some kind of training with firearms. Accidents hardly ever happen. Don't believe me? Look at the stats.
Protecting yourself from criminals is only one reason to own a gun (and because they're criminal they don't care about the law so they'll find a gun anyway). An even better reason for the public to be allowed to own weapons is that it protects against government usurpations. It is no coincidence that one of the first things any totalitarian regime does is take away guns. If the government takes your rights and those of others and you don't have a gun, what's the best you can do? Challenge it in court, what if they're in on it? Go and throw rocks at them, they'll just pick you off with 50 calibers. The second amendment and the tenth (as if it is enforced) are the safeguards of your liberty, not the first or any other provision.

The Founders did not expect droves of citizens to trek un-armed to Camps of Instruction whereat they would be armed. On that note, see also U.S. v. Miller, which is often wrongly cited as a case against the individual RKBA:  "The signification attributed to the term Militia appears from the debates in the Convention, the history and legislation of the Colonies and the States, and the writings of approved commentators. These show plainly enough that the militia comprised all males physically capable of acting in concert for the common defense. "A body of citizens enrolled for military discipline." And further, that ordinarily when called for service these men were expected to appear bearing arms supplied by themselves and of a kind in common use at the time." United States v. Miller, 307 U.S. 174, 179 (1939).  The goal was to ensure an armed populace, and then draw upon the members of that armed populace for the militia.  ---  "Little more can reasonably be aimed at with respect to the people at large than to have them properly armed and equipped. . . .This will not only lessen the call for military establishments, but if circumstances should at any time oblige the government to form an army of any magnitude that army can never be formidable to the liberties of the people while there is a large body of citizens, little if any inferior to them in discipline and the use of arms, who stand ready to defend their rights and those of their fellow citizens." Alexander Hamilton, The Federalist Papers #29, reprinted at page 185 in The Federalist Papers, Mentor Books, 1969, edited by Clinton Rossiter.  "The power of the sword, say the minority of Pennsylvania, is in the hands of Congress. My friends and countrymen, it is not so, for the powers of the sword are in the hands of the yeomanry of America from sixteen to sixty. The militia of these free commonwealths, entitled and accustomed to their arms, when compared with any possible army, must be tremendous and irresistible. Who are the militia? Are they not ourselves? Is it feared, then, that we shall turn our arms each man against his own bosom? Congress shall have no power to disarm the militia. Their swords and every other terrible implement of the soldier, are the birth-right of an American ....[T]he unlimited power of the sword is not in the hands of either the federal or the state governments, but where I trust in God it will ever remain, in the hands of the People." Tench Coxe, Pennsylvania Gazette, Feb. 20, 1788.
