Alright this is where I'm most at home on the board, this is my opinion on gun control.  The only gun control that I feel we need in this country is the basic background check, and serious penalties relating exclusively to criminals who possess firearms.  We need to scale back the list of prohibited people, in such that we repeal the Lautenburg Amendment. As it is right now anybody charged (but not found guilty) of domestic violence is banned for life from being in possession of a firearm. Even if the charge is later found to be false and made by a nut with a history of lying, the charge remains on your record and is EXTREMELY hard to ever get expunged.  We need to limit the power of the BATFE and scale them back to a more controlled and managle level. Currently they have outright control over everything regarding firearms and has constantly contradicted itself, and harmed innocent people. They treat a paperwork error as a willful violation of federal law and revoke FFL licenses on a whim, they don't even follow their own guidelines.  We need to change how something qualifies as a destructive device, AOW, or short barreled shotgun or rifle. We should also see about removing some of the things on the list.  We should end the 1986 machinegun ban so people can buy new machineguns of modern design; nobody's being killed with the pre '86 version, why would post '86 models be unreasonable?  We need to stop the nonsense of banning "assault weapons" closing the "gunshow loophole" licensing and registering firearms and ammunition in any and all forms, requiring gun owners to report their firearms lost or stolen within 72 hours, ending firearms preemption, banning ammunition that can penetrate police body armor, and all that other nonsense! We need to do away with it because it amounts to absolutely NOTHING!  What we really need to do is get very tough on crime, to the point where it borders on cruel and unusual punishment. From now on we need to put an immediate end to all plea deals, suspended sentences and parole for criminals with firearms charges against them. Armed criminals need a minimum of five years just for being armed, gun traffickers need a minimum of ten years for every gun illegally bought and trafficked, these need to be mandatory on state levels, etc.  I'm tired of pandering to the criminals while gun owners are violated by the law. It has to stop!

The same Home Office survey you linked to shows:   17% of total violent crime was 'common assault with NO injury' (i.e. pushing and shoving, spitting at someone or verbal abuse)   43% was 'common assault with less serious injury' (e.g, a scuffle outside a bar)  20% were 'harrassment - no injuries suffered.  5% were 'other violent crimes' including carrying a weapon. As for the knife culture of the UK, people are less likely to die from knife wounds than gun wounds. Guns make it easier to kill at a distance which makes it harder for a victim to run away. You might be able to outrun a person with a knife, but it's harder to outrun a bullet.  This whole statement is nothing more than a complete fallacy, brought on by the supporters of gun control to try and scare people. Watch as I destroy it with my real world knowledge.  The first statement "As for the knife culture of the UK, people are less likely to die from knife wounds than gun wounds" this is just completely false. A knife wound can just as easily lead to your death as a gun wound, and the lethality of each relies on a little something us in the game of target shooting refer to as "placement". Whether you're shot or simply stabbed, you're highly unlikely to die or bleed to death if you're hit in a nonvital area like the shoulder or the hand or the thigh, because there just plain isn't that much in the way that qualifies as a vital sector.  The way people die when shot or stabbed is when a major blood vessle is damaged, resorting in heavy blood loss in a very short amount of time, or a vital organ or the nervous system is dealt a critical blow. And this can be acheived easily with either a knife, gun or any other type of impliment. Some might argue a knife is even MORE deadly than a gun because once the blade enters your body it keeps following a single course and won't fragment like a bullet, allowing it to penetrate deeper.  The second statement "Guns make it easier to kill at a distance which makes it harder for a victim to run away" is completely illogical. While it's true guns are better for use as a distance tool than a knife, that doesn't necessarily make it any easier to kill someone. If you can't aim properly and you can't hit what you're trying to aim at then you're not doing much as all except wasting money, and ammo is getting to be very expensive these days. And anybody who hasn't practiced heavily with their guns will tell you, hitting a moving target is very, if not extremely, difficult. If somebody is jumping around and not allowing you to do a target acquisition then by the time you fire they're likely going to be somewhere else when the bullet leaves your gun.  The third statement "You might be able to outrun a person with a knife, but it's harder to outrun a bullet" is just plain crazy. This assumes that you're actually trying to avoid being shot by running faster than the bullet will travel. As with the second statement, guns are only dangerous if they can actually hit something, otherwise they're nothing more than an expensive noisemaker. It's not a matter of having to outrun a bullet, it's a matter of not being in the direct path of a bullet, and this is actually easier than it sounds.   And if you run away from an attacker, you're actually gonna be more likely to be murdered if you force them to give chase to you when they have a knife. They don't want a hassle, and if you give it to them they might murder you out of anger when they had no plans to. Take if from somebody's that's been known to throw an appliance when it refuses to work properly, or snap a pencil in half when the lead breaks.

I stumbled upon this site by following a link posted on a gun forum that I frequent, which should give a hint as to which side of this debate I'll be speaking up for.  First, since this is my first post here and I've only been perusing this site for an hour or so, I need to know if the "anti-gunners" that are posting in this thread are Americans or not. It seems to me that the site is frequented by a rather diverse, international group of people, and if I'm right about that, then I think I know the problem with convincing them of the incorrect way they are evaluating private gun ownership in America.   Even if every single one of the antis posting here is American, the problem is the same; it's an abject lack of understanding of what our Constitution does and from whom our rights derive. Our government was not put together with the notion that those who hold powerful positions are the givers or guarantors of our rights, they are the protectors of them, nothing more, nothing less. God is who, according to our Founding Fathers, our rights derive from, and those of us who agree with that premise get a little testy when mere mortals try to use the protectors of our rights (our government) to contravene the authority of the giver and guarantor of them (God).   Now, I'm not trying to take this discussion in an off-topic direction and make it about religion. The premise that I describe above is not dependent upon anyone evaluating the existence, or lack thereof, of God in order to accept it as fact. It simply is a hard, cold, wholly provable fact that our Founders believed deeply in the accuracy of that premise, and that they wrote The Constitution with the conviction that they were writing what they perceived God wanted them to write as the cornerstone of its foundation. So if one asks what Madison or Jefferson had in their minds as it relates to the 2nd Amendment, if you take some of their more salient quotes on the subject and combine that with the knowledge that everything they put to writing in our founding documents were directives from God, then there can be no more valid debate about gun control in America without first talking about repealing The Constitution, thus rejecting the permanently-held view of historians and legal scholars since our country's inception that God controls our destiny, not man and/or man's laws. Like it or not, accept the premise or not, believe in God or not, that is precisely what anti-gunners are up against if they want to effectively repeal the 2nd Amendment's original meaning and intent through legislative fiat. And I can back that up.....  "Whereas civil-rulers, not having their duty to the people duly before them, may attempt to tyrannize, and as military forces, which must be occasionally raised to defend our country, might pervert their power to the injury of their fellow citizens, the people are confirmed by the article in their right to keep and bear their private arms." -- Tench Coxe, in Remarks on the First Part of the Amendments to the Federal Constitution   "The best we can hope for concerning the people at large is that they be properly armed."  -- Alexander Hamilton, The Federalist Papers at 184-188   "If the representatives of the people betray their constituents, there is then no recourse left but in the exertion of that *original right of self-defense which is paramount to all positive forms of government, and which against the usurpations of the national rulers may be exerted with infinitely better prospect of success than against those of the rulers of an individual State. In a single State, if the persons entrusted with supreme power become usurpers, the different parcels, subdivisions, or districts of which it consists, having no distinct government in each, can take no regular measures for defense. The citizens must rush tumultuously to arms, without concert, without system, without resource; except in their courage and despair." -- Alexander Hamilton, Federalist No. 29 *My note: All "original rights" come from God, and that is the perspective from which Hamilton uttered these words.  "That the said Constitution *shall never be construed to authorize Congress to infringe the just liberty of the press or the rights of conscience; or to prevent the people of the United States who are peaceable citizens from keeping their own arms ... "  -- Samuel Adams, Debates and Proceedings in the Convention of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, at 86-87 (Pierce & Hale, eds., Boston, 1850) *My note: "Shall never be construed" means exactly that; the right was granted to man by God and cannot be overridden by man or man's laws for perpetuity. That's a long time! No matter how you slice it, 230 years doesn't even scratch the surface of how long this right was supposed to be protected by our government!  "Before a standing army can rule, the people must be disarmed; as they are in almost every kingdom in Europe. The supreme power in America cannot enforce unjust laws by the sword; because the whole body of the people are armed, and constitute a force superior to any band of regular troops that can be, on any pretense, raised in the United States. A military force, at the command of Congress, can execute no laws, but such as the people perceive to be just and constitutional; for they will possess the power, and jealousy will instantly inspire the inclination, to resist the execution of a law which appears to them unjust and oppressive." --Noah Webster, An Examination of the Leading Principles of the Federal Constitution (Philadelphia 1787).   Maybe it is the case that both Americans and non-Americans alike have never been made aware of just how conclusive the righteousness of the 2nd Amendment, as well as all the others, was thought to be by our Founding Fathers. Maybe they don't realize that, to a man, every single one of them can be quoted describing the 2A as protecting an individual right, no different in its' importance to the governance of the citizenry, in a well-ordered society, than the 1st through 10th Amendments were/are. If present-day government is allowed to damage the strength and unalienable nature of the 2nd Amendment through tyrannical legislation which subverts the supreme authority of the document that grants them their power in the first place, what's to stop them from doing the same to any of the other amendments or precepts of the greatest document ever devised by man?   You anti-gunners are perfectly within your rights to be anti-gunners. You are not, however, within your rights to demand of your government, or *our* government as the case may be, that they treat one amendment to The Constitution as less important, less fundamental, less unalienable than any other. If you want to be treated with respect for expressing views which our form of government guarantees is your God-given, fundamental, unalienable right to do, no matter who or how strongly someone may disagree with you, then you have to extend to us the same respect for exercising those rights which are guaranteed to us as gun owners with equal power and force of law. Instead of saying, "There should be gun bans in America," say, "I have banned guns in my home and have decided not to expose my children to them because I feel they cause more trouble than they're worth." The former says you want our government to break the very set of laws that grants its' power, and the latter says that you have chosen to accept the law for what it is and made a personal decision, that steps on no gun-owner's or The Constitution's toes in any way, to take action that is within your legal power to effectuate in your own life and home. Make sense?  Seekerrr

[QUOTE=Ghost Rider;305549]What would you suggest as reasonable gun control laws?  Well, I look to the main intent of the 2nd Amendment, which was at least as much about one's ability to defend themselves and their families, as it was about defending the country from usurpers, even if those usurpers happened to be Americans and/or American politicians. "Reasonable" is relative to the threat you face. In deciding "reasonable" armament to enforce The Constitution from a run amok government, I would focus on the word "arms," as in "...to keep and bear arms...." I can agree that nukes and missile batteries might not fall within a strict definition of "arms." Arms, as used by the Framers, probably referred to small arms, things that could be carried and wielded by hand. The reason I say that the bigger armament "might not" fall into the protected right category is that there is a lot of history in the U.S. of private ownership of cannon and mortar, and I don't recall ever reading about a 2nd Amendment ruling that said they weren't included in the protected right, but I wouldn't feel put-upon if the SCOTUS decided they weren't. I do however, feel very put-upon that I have to ask permission, any degree of permission, to exercise my right to own whatever weapon I want that is at least as effective in combat as any of the small arms that the government might bring to bear against us. I believe to my core that this is a reasonable reading of the 2nd Amendment, and it is most certainly consistent with the reasons that many Framers stated for including the 2nd in the Bill of Rights.  I believe that "realistically" we have allowed Congress, presidents and the courts to engage in usurpation already. I am not willing to voluntarily concede more constitutional ground, and I am frankly disappointed when I see/hear gun-owners and self-proclaimed 2nd Amendment proponents offer such vast amounts of concessions simply to appear "reasonable" to those who would send our government to our homes to take our guns by force if they had that authority. To me, it's analogous to George Washington sending an envoy to Cornwallis' encampment at Yorktown to offer compromise on thoroughly trouncing him in the final battle because to do such would make the King and the people back in England think negatively of the Revolutionary Army. Who on our side should've cared what they thought? And why should you or I care what gun-grabbers think of our willingness (or in my case, unwillingness) to compromise today? I have a real hard time even thinking about compromising what our Founders bequeathed us as fundamental, unalienable rights. And that my friend, is imminently reasonable. I believe that private citizens should be allowed to own cannons and mortars in most circumstances. The battles of Lexington and Concord, which initiated the revelutionary war, were fought in defense of armories containing cannons. This is significant on several levels. Firts of all, they were not fighting to defend an armory of small arms, because they kept those in their homes or they would bear them on their person. Next, it demonstrates how centralized armories are easy targets for the government in order to disarm the people. Further, it shows to importance of artillery in a revelutionary movement.  Now, I understand that some modern cannons can do catastrophic damage, far too great a power to be trusted to any citizen. http://www.atf.gov/firearms/firearmstech/fabriquen.htm  "1/20/05   In response to numerous questions that ATF has received regarding the capabilities of the 5.7 X 28mm cartridge, the following technical information is provided.  FTB classified SS196 ammunition as not armor piercing.   The FN 5.7 (Fabrique Nationale) pistol is a semiautomatic pistol in 5.7 X 28 mm caliber.   The FN 5.7 (Fabrique Nationale) pistol is a semiautomatic pistol in 5.7 X 28 mm caliber approved for importation as a sporting firearm.   The classification of all ammunition is governed strictly by the definitions presented in the GCA. Specifically, as defined in 18 U.S.C. Section 921(a)(17)(B), the term "armor piercing ammunition" means-  a projectile or projectile core which may be used in a handgun and which is constructed entirely (excluding the presence of traces of other substances) from one or a combination of tungsten alloys, steel, iron, brass, bronze, beryllium copper, or depleted uranium; or  a full jacketed projectile larger than .22 caliber designed and intended for use in a handgun and whose jacket has a weight of more than 25 percent of the total weight of the projectile.   FTB has also examined a 5.7 X 28 mm projectile that FN Herstal has designated the "SS196." The SS196 is loaded with a Hornady 40 grain, jacketed lead bullet. FTB classified SS196 ammunition as not armor piercing ammunition under Federal firearms statutes.   According to FNH USA, FN Herstal tested the SS192 ammunition. SS192 ammunition did not penetrate the Level IIIA vests that were tested. FNH USA states that SS196, Hornady V-Max 40 gr. bullets fired from a 4-3/4 inch barrel did not penetrate the Level II vests that were used in testing.   FNH USA has informed FTB that SS192 is no longer imported for commercial sale to the United States and that commercial sales of 5.7 X 28mm ammunition are restricted to the SS196 (not armor piercing)."

All civilian-legal game hunting cartridges, and even several pistol cartridges, are capable of such penetration. I'm not exactly a supporter of gun culture, but I do know some stuff about the Five-seveN. Mostly because it's conceived around the same 5.7 ammo as the P-90 PDW.  Essentially, the smaller firearms, pistols and submachine guns, tend to use larger caliber, but shorter ammunition (9mm, .45, ...). These have good "stopping power", however, the lower propellant charge and blunt shape of the bullet make them less capable at penetrating personal armor. A rifle, any rifle, including hunting rifles, uses much smaller caliber (compare 5.56mm to 9mm), which is however much longer and has a much greater penetrating power.  Essentially, take it liek this: a 9mm is short but fat, 9mm diameter alond the whole cartridge. 5.56 has a thin, sharp, bullet, but a broader and longer body which also contains more propellant, so it shoots the bullet out with much more force compared. The sharper bullet shape also helps penetration.  With armor becoming more and more prevalent, FN Herstal desired to create a handgun/submachine gun cartridge that would be capable of penetrating armor. So they came up with the 5.7 cartridge, specifically designed to penetrate armor.   Essentially, a sharp bullet with a short but thick body.   However, the key to the armor penetration is the specific cartridge. The armor piercing property is bound to the specific ammo, not the gun itself. So, I'd say that if other handguns are on the market, the Five-seveN is just as guilty or innocent as they are. The armor piercing property is only granted by the specialized ammo.

In 2002, for the fourth consecutive year, gun crime in England and Wales rose &#8212; by 35 percent for all firearms, and by a whopping 46 percent for the banned handguns. Nearly 10,000 firearms offenses were committed.... Clearly since the ban criminals have not found it difficult to get guns and the balance has not shifted in the interest of public safety....  In the four years from 1997 to 2001 the rate of violent crime more than doubled. The UK murder rate for 2002 was the highest for a century....  A recent study of all the countries of western Europe has found that in 2001 Britain had the worst record for killings, violence and burglary, and its citizens had one of the highest risks in the industrialized world of becoming victims of crime....  And here&#8217;s the icing on the cake: &#8220;[A] United Nations study of eighteen industrialized countries, including the United States, published in 2002 ... found England and Wales at the top of the Western world&#8217;s crime league, with the worst record for &#8216;very serious&#8217; offenses.&#8221; [Emphasis added]  And all this while crime in the United States, including violent crime, has been steadily falling. I disagree with the argument that the presense of a weapon gives rise to the motive to commit a crime, and that I am less safe with a gun than without.  ---  "And indeed, gentlemen, there exists a law, not written down anywhere but written in our hearts; a law which comes to us not by training or custom or reading but by derivation and absorption and adoption from nature itself; a law which has come to us not by theory but from practice, not by instruction but by natural intuition. I refer to the law which lays it down that, if our lives are endangered by plots or violence or armed robbers or enemies, any and every method of protecting ourselves is morally right. When weapons reduce them to silence, the laws no longer expect one to await their pronouncements. For people who decide to wait for these will have to wait for justice, too--and meanwhile they must suffer injustice first. Indeed, even the wisdom of the law itself, by a sort of tacit implication, permits self- defense, because it does not actually forbid men to kill; what it does, instead, is to forbid the bearing of a weapon with the intention to kill. When, therefore, an inquiry passes beyond the mere question of the weapon and starts to consider the motive, a man who has used arms in self-defense is not regarded as having carried them with homicidal aim". Cicero, Selected Political Speeches, p. 222 (M. Grant, trans. 1975)  "If a slave, says Plato, defends himself, and kills a freeman, he ought to be treated as a parricide. This is a civil law which punishes self-defense, though dictated by nature. . . .It is unreasonable. . .to oblige a man not to attempt the defense of his own life. . . .Who does not see that self-defense is a duty superior to every precept. . . .[T]he laws of an Italian republic, where bearing fire-arms is punished as a capital crime and where it is not more fatal to make an ill use of them than to carry them, is not agreeable to the nature of things." Ah, Archangel, if only you understood basic maths.  Let's take two countries, A and B. A has a population of 100,000 and B has a population of 200,000. To make up some more figures, lets say 5 people were killed in A last year and 20 were killed in B. So, you want to combine the two.  Country/Total Homicide (per 100,000)  A------/5 (5 killed of 100,000, so 5 per 100,000) B------/10 (20 killed of 200,000, so 10 per 100,000)  Correct version: A&B---/8.3 (25 killed of 300,000, so 8.3 per 100,000)   NOT Archangel's version: A&B---/15 (Look, I added up the figures! That's right, isn't it...?)  To combine A and B you need to take a weighted average of the two values, as the values are fractions per population value NOT pure figures. I'm for a few laws, like keeping them away from felons, mentally, etc those kinds of things. I am NOT for complete bans on certain type of firearm (i.e Assault Weapons, etc), or licensing (it's useless), registering, or banning gun shows (evidence shows that a very small percentage of criminals get them at gun shows, there is no point in banning them), safety locks (that is the responsibility of the owner), requirements on guns to be safe (chamber loaded indicators, magazine disconnects, the latter which can cause a fire arm to be unreliable).   I agree with you on most of these thinks. But I do think that we should have safety locks because they do save lives. And I know way too many rednecks (while I am a gunowner, I usually don't like to be thought of as "redneck") who are just too proud to put safety locks on their guns. And besides, all you have to do to turn a safety lock off is push a button. And I think guns should be safe. Other than that I totally agree with you.
